attributes.title: Pre-register_meta-analysis
attributes.description: Remote ischemic conditioning (RIC) has been viewed as an innovative and promising cardioprotective technique, given encouraging results from animal models and clinical studies in the past decade, showing potential benefits in increasing myocardial salvage and reducing infarction size after primary percutaneous coronary intervention (PPCI) for ST segment elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI). However, trials reporting the effects of RIC on cardiovascular events and death in patients with STEMI have shown conflicting results. Thus, we intended to conduct this study to assess the association of remote ischemic conditioning (RIC) with cardiovascular events and death in ST-segment elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI) patients undergoing primary percutaneous coronary intervention (PPCI) by systematic review and meta-analysis.

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

name.value: Association of remote ischemic conditioning with cardiovascular events and death in patients with ST-segment elevation myocardial infarction undergoing primary percutaneous coronary intervention: a systematic review and meta-analysis of randomized clinical trials

other.value: If appropriate data are available, subgroup analyses will be carried out by duration of follow-up, sample size, different protocols of RIC (pre-RIC or post-RIC), and whether MACE was a prespecified outcome, etc.

sample.value: All RCTs reporting the effects of RIC versus standard care (or sham RIC) on cardiovascular events or death among adults (≥18 years) presenting with STEMI eligible for PPCI will be considered for inclusion.

analyses.value: We will conduct a meta-analysis of randomized clinical trials (RCTs) to assess the effects of RIC versus standard care or sham RIC on cardiovascular outcomes and death. The pooled effect of RIC will be quantified by the relative risk (RR) with its 95% confidence interval (CI). Considering the included studies to be sufficiently similar, we will use a random-effects model to better estimate the effect size of different studies with small samples, and to provide more conservative estimates regardless of the presence of significant heterogeneity. If we include more than 10 trials in this meta-analysis, funnel plots will be used to show publication bias. Meanwhile, we will assess reporting bias qualitatively on the basis of characteristics of included trials if there are less than 10 trials.

outliers.value: Duplicate reports and trials lack of follow-up data on cardiovascular outcomes of interest will be excluded.

dependent.value: Incidence of major adverse cardiovascular events (MACE, including death, heart failure, acute coronary syndrome, repeated revascularization, or stroke/transient ischemic attack) to the last available follow-up.

conditions.value: Adults presenting with STEMI eligible for PPCI.

hypothesis.value: Trials reporting the effects of remote ischemic conditioning (RIC) on outcomes in patients with ST-segment elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI) have shown conflicting results. Can RIC reduce the risk of cardiovascular events and death in STEMI patients undergoing primary percutaneous coronary intervention (PPCI)?

attributes.title: Effects of diabetes mellitus and periodontitis on oxidative stress: a systematic review and meta-analysis

q1.value: Paula Beatriz de Oliveira Nunes, Leonardo de Oliveira Bittencourt, Yago Gecy de Sousa Né, Rafael Rodrigues Lima, Lucianne Cople Maia

q2.value:
Some studies show oxidative stress in some fluids like plasma, saliva, crevicular fluid in patients who have periodontitis, so these systematic reviews want to evaluate the oxidative damage caused by a systemic disease like diabetes and a local disease like periodontitis.
The databases to be searched include:
Pubmed, Scopus, Web of science, Cochrane, Lilacs
The search for unpublished studies will include:
Open Grey

q3.value: Meta-Analysis - A systematic review of published studies.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: This systematic review and meta-analysis will evaluate the effects of diabetes mellitus and periodontitis on oxidative stress, that will collect observational studies following the Prisma Guide in which have P- humans with periodontitis, E- with diabetes, compared to those who haven't diabetes, to know if there is oxidative stress- O.

attributes.title: ACT4Care
attributes.description: Enhance Resilience and Psychological Flexibility am nurses through an online-based Acceptance and Commitment Training (ACT)

q2.value:
Hypothesis Study 1
- The scores on the Burnout-Scale (MBI) will decrease between t0 and t1 in the intervention-group and between t2 and t3 in the waitlist-group, respectively. The score on the Work Engagement Scale (UWES) will increase between t0 and t1 in the intervention-group and between t1 and t2 in the waitlist-group, respectively.
- The intervention-group shows a higher increase in the UWES and a higher decrease in the MBI between t1 and t2 compared to the waitlist-group.
- An increase of the MBI values before the training is associated with a decrease  of the MBI values after the training
- A decrease of the UWES values before the training is associated with an increase of the UWES values after the training
- Subjects who train more frequently benefit more of the training, concerning the aforementioned scales 


Hypothesis Study 2
-The scores of the SOC-L9, FAH-II, MHC-SF increase between t0 and t1, as well as between t1 and t2 in the intervention-group and between t1 and t2 in the waitlist-group, respectively.
-The psychological flexibility impacts the mental health continuum scores with at least a weak effect (f ≥ .10)
-The scores in the aforementioned scales depend on the training frequency; more precisely: subjects with higher training frequency show higher scores

q3.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
The project is conceptualized as a within-between design with three time measure points. A randomized control design with an intervention- and a waitlist-group will be applied. Data will be acquired via online questionnaires through 3 time measure points (t0, t1, t2), including a 3 month follow-up phase for the intervention-group.

After completing the first measures, the subjects will be randomly assigned to one of the two groups. The intervention-group immediately starts with the ACT4Care-Training. The training has a duration of 6 weeks. Six weeks after the completion of the first questionnaire subjects of both intervention- and waitlist-group fill in the second questionnaire. Furthermore, the waitlist-group subsequently commences the training. The third measures will be conducted after the waitlist-group has completed the training, and after the intervention group fulfilled the 3-month follow-up phase, respectively.

q7.value: random assignments will be administered by unipark.de hostet by questback gmbh.

q8.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
Between January and March 2020, nurses in the German speaking areas of Switzerland enroll for the study and the ACT4Care-Training voluntarily, after the study was presented to nurse leaders in somatic and psychiatric hospitals as well as to universities and nursing schools.
All German speaking nurses regardless their type of diploma and with a workload of 60% at minimum are eligible to participate in the study, therefore meet the inclusion criterions. After the study, all subjects obtain the possibility to discuss their experiences during the training with the research leaders. There is no financial incentive for the study participants.

q11.value: Our target sample size is 100 participants. We will attempt to recruit at least 130, assuming that not all will complete the full training and all the questionnaires.

q13.value: Datacollection will be terminated at March 25, 2020.

question.value:
At three timepoints data is collected via online-based questionnaires. The following questionnaires will be administered:
•	Maslach Burnout Inventory German Version (MBI-D) (Büssing & Perrar, 1992; as cited in Korczak, Kister & Huber, 2010)
•	Utrecht Work Engagement Scale (UWES-17) (Schaufeli, Bakker & Salanova, 2006)
•	Sense of Coherence Scale (SOC-L9) (Schumacher, Wilz, Gunzelmann & Brähler, 2000)
•	Fragebogen zu Akzeptanz und Handeln (FAH-II) (Hoyer & Gloster, 2013)
•	Mental Health Continuum Short Form (MHC-SF) (Lamers, Westerhof, Bohlmeijer, Klooster & Keyes, 2011)

Covariates which will be assessed consist of the following: sex, age, type of diploma, current apprenticeship or education, workload, type of institution (somatic, psychiatric, long-term care, home-treatment etc), country, experience with mindfulness techniques (meditation), ongoing resilience training, frequency of training performance with the obtained ACT4Care-material

If data will be normally distributed we will run a multi-way analysis of variance (ANOVA) to test whether there are any main effects of group or measurement times and how the interaction between both of the predictors is like. This will answer our main hypothesis about the effectiveness of our training. As covariates we define the frequency of the training performance to test if there exists such an influence. Furthermore, we will run a multiple regression analysis to test whether there is a correlation between the initial values  in burnout and work engagement and the values in these scales after the training.

In case of many missing datas and absence of normaldistributed data, a generalized estimation equation model (GEE) will be applied to the data. We will use an intention to treat analysis. Missing Data will be replaced with the MCAR-Method.

q23.value:
Our study is approximately basing on a recent work from Hofer et al. (2018):
-Hofer, P. D., Waadt, M., Aschwanden, R., Milidou, M., Acker, J., Meyer, A. H. et al. (2018). Self-help for stress and burnout without therapist contact: An online randomised controlled trial. Work & Stress, 32(2), 189–208. https://doi.org/10.1080/02678373.2017.1402389

The questionnaires are retrieved from the following sources:
-Büssing, A. & Perrar, K.-M. (1992). Die Messung von Burnout. Untersuchung einer deutschen Fassung des Maslach Burnout Inventory (MBI-D). [Measuring burnout: A study of a German version of the Maslach Burnout Inventory (MBI-D).]. Diagnostica, 38(4), 328–353.

-Hoyer, J. & Gloster, A. T. (2013). Psychologische Flexibilität messen: Der Fragebogen zu Akzeptanz und Handeln II. Verhaltenstherapie, 23(1), 42–44. https://doi.org/10.1159/000347040

-Lamers, S. M. A., Westerhof, G. J., Bohlmeijer, E. T., Klooster, P. M. ten & Keyes, C. L. M. (2011). Evaluating the psychometric properties of the mental health Continuum-Short Form (MHC-SF). Journal of Clinical Psychology, 67(1), 99–110. https://doi.org/10.1002/jclp.20741

-Schaufeli, W. B., Bakker, A. B. & Salanova, M. (2006). The Measurement of Work Engagement With a Short Questionnaire: A Cross-National Study. Educational and Psychological Measurement, 66(4), 701–716. https://doi.org/10.1177/0013164405282471

-Schumacher, J., Wilz, G., Gunzelmann, T. & Brähler, E. (2000). Die Sense of Coherence Scale von Antonovsky. PPmP-Psychotherapie, Psychosomatik, Medizinische Psychologie, 50(12), 472–482. https://doi.org/10.1055/s-2000-9207

attributes.title: The dished-in face: a scoping review of surgical treatment options

summary.value:
The objective of the review is to map the available evidence for surgical treatment options and outcome assessment of the dished-in facial profile.

Primary question: What are the surgical treatment options for the dished-in facial profile?
Secondary questions:
- How is the dished-in face defined in literature?
- What is the etiology of the dished-in facial profile?
- How are outcomes assessed after treatment of the dished-in face?
- What is the outcome after treatment of the dished-in face?

attributes.title: Coronavirus
attributes.description: Identifying subgroups who are less likely to comply with official recommendations regarding COVID-19 pandemic.

q2.value:
We expect to replicate previous results, in which we found that:
1. Trait pathogen disgust predicts (past and future) efforts to follow official recommendations regarding the coronavirus outbreak.
2. Harm moral values predict (past and future) efforts to follow official recommendations regarding the coronavirus outbreak.

q3.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: Observational study measuring individual differences.

q8.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Participants will be recruited through the online platform prolific.co. They will be paid 1.88 uk pounds for agreeing to participate. Participants will be screened to obtain a representative sample of the US population.

q11.value: Our target sample size is 204 participants. We will attempt to recruit up to 300, assuming that some participants will fail the attention check questions included in our Moral Values scale (Iyer et al., 2012).

q12.value: We used the software program G*Power to conduct a power analysis. Our goal was to obtain .95 power to detect an effect size of f2 = .15 at the standard .05 alpha error probability for multiple linear regressions using 16 predictors.

question.value:
Dependent variables:

1. Behavior. Participants will be asked (i) how many efforts they made in the past 7 days to follow a set of four  recommendations, and (ii) how many efforts they planned to make in the 7 upcoming days. The four recommendation were: (a) avoiding contact with other people (e.g. not shaking hands), (b) washing hands regularly, (c) staying at home as much as possible, and (d) couching in one’s elbow or a non-reusable tissue rather than in one’s hands. Each recommendation was accompanied by illustrations from the WHO or the CDC.
2. Attitudes. Participants will report their agreement (1 = Fully disagree, 7 = Fully agree) with seven statements about their perception of the coronavirus outbreak: (1) “The COVID-19 is one of the most serious health crises in recent times”, (2) “People are overreacting to the coronavirus outbreak”, (3) “The coronavirus is not really more dangerous than the common flu”, (4) “A lot of people fail to grasp the terrible threat the coronavirus actually represents”, (5) “There is clearly no reason to panic. People are only afraid because they fail to understand what is happening”, and (6) “The US government is not taking the crisis seriously enough”.

Independent variables:

1. Belief in pseudo-science (Majima, 2015).
2. Belief in conspiracy theories (Lantian et al., 2006)
3. Psychological reactance (Hong & Faeda, 1996)
4. Trait pathogen disgust (Tybur et al., 2009)
5. Empathic concern (Davis, 1983)
6. Perspective-taking (Davis, 1983)
7. Moral values (Iyer et al., 2012)
8. Truth is political (Garrett & Weeks, 2017)
9. Faith in intuition (Garrett & Weeks, 2017)
10. Narcissism (Ames et al., 2006)
11. Trait Fear (Kramer et al., 2020)

1. Past behavior. Mean "past efforts" ratings across responses to the four recommendations.
2. Future behavior. Mean "future efforts" ratings across responses to the four recommendations.
3. Attitudes. Mean agreement for the six Attitude statements (with statements 2, 3 and 5 reverse-coded).
4. Mean scores for each independent variable (individual differences scales) will be calculated as indicated by the authors of the cited papers.

1. Linear regression using (1) Belief in pseudo-science, (2) Belief in conspiracy theories (3) Psychological reactance (4) Trait pathogen disgust (5) Empathic concern (6) Perspective-taking (7) Harm moral values (8) Fairness moral values (9) Ingroup moral values (10) Authority moral values (11) Economic Liberty moral values (12) Lifestyle Liberty moral values (13) Truth is political (14) Faith in Intuition and (15) Narcissism and (16) Trait Fear as independent variables, and Past Behavior as the dependent variable.

2. Linear regression using (1) Belief in pseudo-science, (2) Belief in conspiracy theories (3) Psychological reactance (4) Trait pathogen disgust (5) Empathic concern (6) Perspective-taking (7) Harm moral values (8) Fairness moral values (9) Ingroup moral values (10) Authority moral values (11) Economic Liberty moral values (12) Lifestyle Liberty moral values (13) Truth is political (14) Faith in Intuition and (15) Narcissism and (16) Trait Fear as independent variables and Future Behavior as the dependent variable.

We expect to replicate previous results, in which we found that:
1. Trait pathogen disgust predicts (past and future) efforts to follow official recommendations regarding the coronavirus outbreak.
2. Harm moral values predict (past and future) efforts to follow official recommendations regarding the coronavirus outbreak.

registration_responses.q10.question: Participants will be recruited through the online platform prolific.co. They will be paid 1.88 uk pounds for agreeing to participate. Participants will be screened to obtain a representative sample of the US population.
registration_responses.q15.question:
Dependent variables:

1. Behavior. Participants will be asked (i) how many efforts they made in the past 7 days to follow a set of four  recommendations, and (ii) how many efforts they planned to make in the 7 upcoming days. The four recommendation were: (a) avoiding contact with other people (e.g. not shaking hands), (b) washing hands regularly, (c) staying at home as much as possible, and (d) couching in one’s elbow or a non-reusable tissue rather than in one’s hands. Each recommendation was accompanied by illustrations from the WHO or the CDC.
2. Attitudes. Participants will report their agreement (1 = Fully disagree, 7 = Fully agree) with seven statements about their perception of the coronavirus outbreak: (1) “The COVID-19 is one of the most serious health crises in recent times”, (2) “People are overreacting to the coronavirus outbreak”, (3) “The coronavirus is not really more dangerous than the common flu”, (4) “A lot of people fail to grasp the terrible threat the coronavirus actually represents”, (5) “There is clearly no reason to panic. People are only afraid because they fail to understand what is happening”, and (6) “The US government is not taking the crisis seriously enough”.

Independent variables:

1. Belief in pseudo-science (Majima, 2015).
2. Belief in conspiracy theories (Lantian et al., 2006)
3. Psychological reactance (Hong & Faeda, 1996)
4. Trait pathogen disgust (Tybur et al., 2009)
5. Empathic concern (Davis, 1983)
6. Perspective-taking (Davis, 1983)
7. Moral values (Iyer et al., 2012)
8. Truth is political (Garrett & Weeks, 2017)
9. Faith in intuition (Garrett & Weeks, 2017)
10. Narcissism (Ames et al., 2006)
11. Trait Fear (Kramer et al., 2020)
registration_responses.q16.question:
1. Past behavior. Mean "past efforts" ratings across responses to the four recommendations.
2. Future behavior. Mean "future efforts" ratings across responses to the four recommendations.
3. Attitudes. Mean agreement for the six Attitude statements (with statements 2, 3 and 5 reverse-coded).
4. Mean scores for each independent variable (individual differences scales) will be calculated as indicated by the authors of the cited papers.
registration_responses.q17.question:
1. Linear regression using (1) Belief in pseudo-science, (2) Belief in conspiracy theories (3) Psychological reactance (4) Trait pathogen disgust (5) Empathic concern (6) Perspective-taking (7) Harm moral values (8) Fairness moral values (9) Ingroup moral values (10) Authority moral values (11) Economic Liberty moral values (12) Lifestyle Liberty moral values (13) Truth is political (14) Faith in Intuition and (15) Narcissism and (16) Trait Fear as independent variables, and Past Behavior as the dependent variable.

2. Linear regression using (1) Belief in pseudo-science, (2) Belief in conspiracy theories (3) Psychological reactance (4) Trait pathogen disgust (5) Empathic concern (6) Perspective-taking (7) Harm moral values (8) Fairness moral values (9) Ingroup moral values (10) Authority moral values (11) Economic Liberty moral values (12) Lifestyle Liberty moral values (13) Truth is political (14) Faith in Intuition and (15) Narcissism and (16) Trait Fear as independent variables and Future Behavior as the dependent variable.

attributes.title: Schuell Language Training Combined with Head Acupuncture Alone for the Treatment of Post-Stroke Aphasia: Protocol for A Systematic Review and Meta-Analysis
attributes.description: Aphasia refers to the pathological changes of brain tissues related to language function, such as stroke, brain trauma, brain tumors, brain inflammation, etc., which cause the impairment of the understanding and expression ability of human communicative symbolic system, especially the impairment of phonetics, vocabulary, grammar and other components, the understanding and expression of language structure and the content and meaning of language, and the language cognition as the basis of language. Decrease of process and impairment of function. Schuell language training combined with head acupuncture in the treatment of post-stroke aphasia has done a lot of research, the effect is significant. There are no SR or protocol on Schuell language training combined with head acupuncture for post-stroke aphasia. Therefore, research on it is needed.

Decrease of process and impairment of function. Schuell language training combined with head acupuncture in the treatment of post-stroke aphasia has done a lot of research, the effect is significant. 2. How does the efficacy of Schuell language training combined with head acupuncture compare to that with Western medicine therapies alone, other TCM therapies alone, blank control, placebo control and other interventions? 
3. There are some moderating variables associated with prevention and treatment efficacy in studies of Schuell language training combined with head acupuncture for patients with post-stroke aphasia.

q7.value:
Three reviewers searched the online databases listed above and recorded the titles and abstracts of all the articles.
Three evaluators assessed the eligibility of these articles and made decisions on every research (inclusion or exclusion) independently. If they did not reach the same decision, the concerned articles were discussed with a fourth reviewer.
Three reviewers extracted data independently from each study.
Differences regarding the extracted data were resolved after discussion with a fourth reviewer.
Three authors of our review team will independently assess the methodological quality of included trials, and consensus will be reached by discussion with a third party in case of discrepancy.

The methodological quality of RCTs will be assessed according to the risk of bias tool described in the Cochrane Handbook for Systematic Reviews of Interventions [Higgins JPT 2009]. Six elements will be assessed: random sequence generation, allocation concealment, blinding of outcome assessors, incomplete outcome data, free of selective reporting, and other bias. Disagreements will be resolved by discussion with a third party.

question.value:
1. Anticipated start date: 23/10/2019;

2. Anticipated completion date: 24/02/2020;

3.Review question: ①. Is Schuell language training combined with head acupuncture effective for patients with post-stroke aphasia? 
                ②. How does the efficacy of Schuell language training combined with head acupuncture compare to that with TCM therapies alone, Western medicine therapies alone, blank control, placebo control and other interventions? 
                ③. What moderating variables are associated with treatment efficacy in studies of Schuell language training combined with head acupuncture for patients with post-stroke aphasia? 

4. Searches: All published and unpublished RCTs of the Schuell language training combined with head acupuncture alone for post-stroke aphasia will be searchedin in English and Chinese databases.
The following sources will be searched from inception to October 9, 2019.
1. EMBASE (Ovid);
2. The Cochrane Library;
3. SinoMed;
4. CNKI (China National Knowledge Infrastructure);
5. VIP (VIP Database for Chinese Technical Periodicals);
6. Wanfang Database.
7. PubMed
We will also search the references of the original and review articles manually for possible related trials, and also tried to get grey literatures identified through other sources.
One month will be allocated for data collection and one month for article analysis.
Retrieval time is from the inception dates of the databases to 28 Oct, 2020.
We also considered the alternative terms and spellings for keywords.
In addition, the references of initially included literature were traced back to achieve a comprehensive search. English and Chinese language were included.
Additional search strategy information can be found in the attached PDF document (link provided below).

5. Condition or domain being studied: Aphasia refers to the pathological changes of brain tissues related to language function, such as stroke, brain trauma, brain tumors, brain inflammation, etc., which cause the impairment of the understanding and expression ability of human communicative symbolic system, especially the impairment of phonetics, vocabulary, grammar and other components, the understanding and expression of language structure and the content and meaning of language, and the language cognition as the basis of language. Decrease of process and impairment of function. Schuell language training combined with head acupuncture in the treatment of post-stroke aphasia has done a lot of research, the effect is significant. There are no SR or protocol on Schuell language training combined with head acupuncture for post-stroke aphasia. Therefore, research on it is needed.

6.Participants/population: Male or female, aged 18 years or older, diagnosed as having had a stroke, with defined aphasia. Studies in English and Chinese will be included. are eligible for inclusion.

7. Intervention(s), exposure(s): Treatment of Schuell language training combined with head acupuncture alone, including ordinary acupuncture, electro-acupuncture, needle, fire needle and plum blossom needle.

8. Comparator(s)/control: Including language rehabilitation alone, head acupuncture alone, western medicine alone, or sham acupuncture, blank control, placebo control and other interventions. Interventions in the experimental group were not included.

9. Types of study to be included: We will include randomised controlled trials (RCTs), published and unpublished, in English and Chinese.

10. Main outcome(s): Main outcomes include the Boston diagnostic aphasia (BDAE), Aphasia quotient (AQ), Chinese Functional Communication Profile (CFCP), Communicative Abilities of Daily Living (CADL), and total effective rate, which is the sum of "effective rate" and " markedly effective rate".

11. Additional outcome(s): ① Western Aphasia Battery (WAB);
② Bilingual aphasia test (BAT);
③ Comprehensive Aphasia Test (CAT);
④ Aphasia Rapid Test (ART);
⑤ China Rehabilitation Research Center Aphasia Examination (CRRCAE);
⑥ Aphasia Battery of Chinese (ABC).
If we find other measurements that are suitable and standard for the trials, we will discuss them and decide whether to include them or not.

12. Data extraction (selection and coding): Three reviewers (Qinwei Fu, Jing Feng and Lanzhi Zhang) searched the online databases listed above and recorded the titles and abstracts of all the articles. Three evaluators (Xinyun Hu, Lixin Yang and Yunxiang Zhao) assessed the eligibility of these articles and made decisions on every research (inclusion or exclusion) independently. If they did not reach the same decision, the concerned articles were discussed with a fourth reviewer (Qinxiu Zhang). Three reviewers (Jing Feng, Yunxiang Zhao, and Hui Yang) extracted data independently from each study. Differences of extracted data were solved after discussion with a fourth reviewer (Qinwei Fu).

13.Risk of bias (quality) assessment: Three authors of our review team will independently assess the methodological quality of included trials, and consensus will be reached by discussion with a third party in case of discrepancy.
The methodological quality of RCTs will be assessed according to the risk of bias tool described in the Cochrane Handbook for Systematic Reviews of Interventions [Higgins JPT 2009]. Six elements will be assessed: random sequence generation, allocation concealment, blinding of outcome assessors, incomplete outcome data, free of selective reporting, and other bias. Disagreements will be resolved by discussion with a third party.

14. Strategy for data synthesis: Statistical analyses will be performed using RevMan 5.3 software (The Cochrane Collaboration).
- Pooled risk ratio (RR) with 95% confidence interval (CI) of dichotomous outcomes will be used to report effect estimate.
- Continuous data will be presented as mean difference (MD) with 95% CI. If different measurement scales are used, standardized mean difference (SMD) will be performed to analyze continuous data.
If required data are not reported, we will try to obtain data from corresponding author.
Heterogeneity will be assessed using both the χ² test and the I² statistic, and we will consider an I² value greater than 50% indicative of substantial heterogeneity.
- For I²<50%, a fixed-effect model is used.
- For I² >=50%, a random-effect model is applied.
If data permit, we plan to exclude some trials that contribuite most to the heterogeneity to see whether the result change or not.
We will also use a summary of findings table to present the main findings using GRADEpro software (The Cochrane Collaboration). Funnel plots will be generated to detect publication bias if more than 10 trials are identified to report the same outcomes. If appropriate, we will use cumulative meta-analyses. Results of meta-analyses will be visualized by forest plots. In addition, we will conduct trial sequential analysis to evaluate the meta-analyses for primary outcomes, which can reveal the required information size and potentially false results in a meta-analysis. Intention-to-treat analysis will be applied for primary outcome, if missing data from the original trials are available.

15. Analysis of subgroups or subsets: If data permitted, we plan to conduct subgroup analyses for different groups, including:
Different age of patients
Different severity of disease
Different regimen applied
Different treat time
Different acupoints selected
Combined with other interventions or not.

16. Type and method of review: intervention; Meta-analysis; Prevention; Systematic review.

17. Languages of the review: English and Chinese;

18. Dissemination plans: In addition to producing a report, a paper will be submitted to a journal in this field.

19. Keywords: Schuell’s language training; Head acupuncture; Aphasia after stroke; Systematic review; Meta-analysis.

Three evaluators (Xinyun Hu, Lixin Yang and Yunxiang Zhao) assessed the eligibility of these articles and made decisions on every research (inclusion or exclusion) independently. If they did not reach the same decision, the concerned articles were discussed with a fourth reviewer (Qinxiu Zhang). Three reviewers (Jing Feng, Yunxiang Zhao, and Hui Yang) extracted data independently from each study. Differences of extracted data were solved after discussion with a fourth reviewer (Qinwei Fu).

13.Risk of bias (quality) assessment: Three authors of our review team will independently assess the methodological quality of included trials, and consensus will be reached by discussion with a third party in case of discrepancy.
The methodological quality of RCTs will be assessed according to the risk of bias tool described in the Cochrane Handbook for Systematic Reviews of Interventions [Higgins JPT 2009]. Six elements will be assessed: random sequence generation, allocation concealment, blinding of outcome assessors, incomplete outcome data, free of selective reporting, and other bias. Disagreements will be resolved by discussion with a third party.

14. Strategy for data synthesis: Statistical analyses will be performed using RevMan 5.3 software (The Cochrane Collaboration).
- Pooled risk ratio (RR) with 95% confidence interval (CI) of dichotomous outcomes will be used to report effect estimate.
- Continuous data will be presented as mean difference (MD) with 95% CI. If different measurement scales are used, standardized mean difference (SMD) will be performed to analyze continuous data.
If required data are not reported, we will try to obtain data from corresponding author.
Heterogeneity will be assessed using both the χ² test and the I² statistic, and we will consider an I² value greater than 50% indicative of substantial heterogeneity.
- For I²<50%, a fixed-effect model is used.
- For I² >=50%, a random-effect model is applied.
If data permit, we plan to exclude some trials that contribuite most to the heterogeneity to see whether the result change or not.
We will also use a summary of findings table to present the main findings using GRADEpro software (The Cochrane Collaboration). Funnel plots will be generated to detect publication bias if more than 10 trials are identified to report the same outcomes. If appropriate, we will use cumulative meta-analyses. Results of meta-analyses will be visualized by forest plots. In addition, we will conduct trial sequential analysis to evaluate the meta-analyses for primary outcomes, which can reveal the required information size and potentially false results in a meta-analysis. Intention-to-treat analysis will be applied for primary outcome, if missing data from the original trials are available.

15. Analysis of subgroups or subsets: If data permitted, we plan to conduct subgroup analyses for different groups, including:
Different age of patients
Different severity of disease
Different regimen applied
Different treat time
Different acupoints selected
Combined with other interventions or not.

16. Type and method of review: intervention; Meta-analysis; Prevention; Systematic review.

17. Languages of the review: English and Chinese;

18. Dissemination plans: In addition to producing a report, a paper will be submitted to a journal in this field.

19. Keywords: Schuell’s language training; Head acupuncture; Aphasia after stroke; Systematic review; Meta-analysis.
registration_responses.q12.question:
1. Searches: All published and unpublished RCTs of the Schuell language training combined with head acupuncture alone for post-stroke aphasia will be searchedin in English and Chinese databases.
The following sources will be searched from inception to October 9, 2019.
1. EMBASE (Ovid);
2. The Cochrane Library;
3. SinoMed;
4. CNKI (China National Knowledge Infrastructure);
5. VIP (VIP Database for Chinese Technical Periodicals);
6. Wanfang Database.
7. PubMed
We will also search the references of the original and review articles manually for possible related trials, and also tried to get grey literatures identified through other sources.
One month will be allocated for data collection and one month for article analysis.
Retrieval time is from the inception dates of the databases to 28 Oct, 2020.
We also considered the alternative terms and spellings for keywords.
In addition, the references of initially included literature were traced back to achieve a comprehensive search. English and Chinese language were included.
Additional search strategy information can be found in the attached PDF document (link provided below).

2.Participants/population: Male or female, aged 18 years or older, diagnosed as having had a stroke, with defined aphasia. Studies in English and Chinese will be included. are eligible for inclusion.

3. Intervention(s), exposure(s): Treatment of Schuell language training combined with head acupuncture alone, including ordinary acupuncture, electro-acupuncture, needle, fire needle and plum blossom needle.

4. Comparator(s)/control: Including language rehabilitation alone, head acupuncture alone, western medicine alone, or sham acupuncture, blank control, placebo control and other interventions. Interventions in the experimental group were not included.

5. Types of study to be included: We will include randomised controlled trials (RCTs), published and unpublished, in English and Chinese.

attributes.title: Comparison of cephalometric indicators between orthodontic camouflage versus orthognathic surgery in Class III malocclusion: A systematic review
attributes.description: To date, there is no systematic review about the indicators of the treatment in Class III malocclusion. Thus, this systematic review will compare the radiographic indicators, lip changes and also complication for orthodontic camouflage and orthognathic surgery in Class III malocclusion.

attributes.title: Individual differences in the relationship between empathy, interoceptive accuracy, and wellbeing.
attributes.description: This project will seek to explore the relationship between interoceptive accuracy, empathy, and both social and non-social wellbeing across different cohorts of the UK population. The data will be drawn from a large survey that we are currently conducting in collaboration with the BBC and Wellcome Collection (to be completed on 30th March 2020). There are a variety of measures in the survey, but for this project we will extract data specific to interoceptive accuracy, empathy and social and non-social wellbeing in order to assess how these factors are related and interact with each other.

data.value: It's complicated. We have already collected some data but explain in Question 8 why readers may consider this a valid pre-registration nevertheless.

name.value: Individual differences in the relationship between empathy, interoceptive accuracy, and wellbeing.

other.value: We may also decide to conduct two forms of secondary analysis. 1) An in depth moderation analysis to more thoroughly explore the moderating effect interoceptive accuracy may have on the relationship between empathy and wellbeing (which will be initially assessed using interaction terms in the regression analyses—described above). 2) An exploratory analysis to identify responder subgroups using cluster analysis techniques (e.g. k-means, finite mixture models, finite mixtures of regression models). The purpose of this will be to take advantage of a large dataset on mental and social wellbeing in relation to interoceptive accuracy and empathy. It will provide future researchers with a detailed taxonomy of individual differences in the nomological network of interoceptive accuracy, empathy, and wellbeing. Our hope is that this will provide a foundation for strong empirical research within the field, helping other scientists to identify useful avenues of research and formulate hypotheses. Note, that in this context we may in future work also seek to explore additional items from the full Interoceptive accuracy Test survey (please see attached file) that are not mentioned as part of our planned analyses above.

sample.value: Our target sample size is a minimum of 954 for each sample that we plan to analyse in our regressions. We will collect a large opportunity sample with the aim of recruiting at least this number of participants for each sample of interest. This sample was determined using a power calculation in G*Power, performed to determine the minimum number of observations required to perform a multiple linear regression with 15 predictor variables to detect small effect sizes (i.e. f2=0.02, α = .05, β = .80). Note, there is a fixed stopping criteria which is the date set for survey completion by the BBC/Wellcome Collection – namely 30th March 2020. Based on similar prior projects run by BBC/Wellcome Collection we envisage a minimum sample of ~20,000 participants from the UK.

analyses.value:
All analyses and statistical tests will be accompanied by reports of standardized effect size and 95% confidence intervals, where applicable

Assumptions of normality will be checked using gg-plots, histograms, and appropriate tests of normality (e.g., Kolmogorov-Smirnov). In the case of moderate skew or kurtosis, log-transformations or similar will be applied. In the cases of extreme deviations from normality, we will apply equivalent non-parametric tests. Any deviations or alterations to these plans will be reported. 

We will use the following alpha levels: <.05 for all correlations (which will be corrected for the total number of correlations that are run), <.01 given sample size for all regressions.

Correlation and regression analysis:
We will examine the correlations between: empathy, interoceptive accuracy, attachment styles, wellbeing and loneliness scales. We predict that there will be positive associations between: empathy-IAS, empathy-mental wellbeing, IAS-mental wellbeing, IAS-loneliness. We predict negative associations between: empathy-IAS, IAS-mental wellbeing, empathy-loneliness, IAS-loneliness. We will us an alpha criterion of .05 that will be corrected for the total number of correlations that are run.

We will conduct separate multiple linear regression models to assess how both interoceptive accuracy and empathy measures relate to mental wellbeing and loneliness, with empathy, interoceptive accuracy subscales, empathy*interoceptive accuracy interaction, attachment style subscales, age, gender, and week of testing included as predictor variables. Statistical significance will be assessed for the overall model, for R Square change, and for individual regressors with an alpha criterion of p < 0.01.

outliers.value:
To deal with outliers in our regression analyses we will use robust regressions where relevant.

Participants will need to have completed at least 80% of each scale or subscale for that data to be included in an analysis. Where less than 80% of items have been completed, data will be excluded. Subscales will be treated individually, where a participant may be excluded from analysis for one subscale, but can still be included in analyses for other subscales on that scale, where data is sufficient. If analysis focuses on a single item/question from the survey we will include all participants who complete the question.

dependent.value: Our main dependent variables of interest are mental and social wellbeing, which will be measured via scores on the Short Warwick–Edinburgh Mental Well-being Scale (Stewart-Brown, 2009) and UCLA Loneliness Scale (Russell, 1996) respectively.

conditions.value:
The study is an online self-report survey comprising several independent scales using an opportunity sample. Variables of interest for the current project are described above/below.

Participants to be included in the analysis will be asked to complete all of the measures. Participants have been recruited through broadcasts on the BBC and other media. There is no monetary incentive to take part. Participants must be aged over 18 years old and have internet access on a computer, smart phone or tablet to participate. Note, there is a fixed stopping criteria which is the date set for survey completion by the BBC/Wellcome Collection – namely 30th March 2020. 

We will assess the following predictor variables to assess how they influence wellbeing:
1.	Empathy: a modified version of the Empathy Quotient Questionnaire (Muncer and Ling, 2006; EQ)—using scores from the emotional reactivity and cognitive empathy subscales.

2.	Interoceptive accuracy: the Interoceptive Accuracy Scale (IAS; Murphy et al., 2020) measuring self-reported interoceptive accuracy (i.e. the ability to accurately detect internal bodily sensations).

3.	Age

4.	Gender

5.	Attachment style: Experiences in Close Relationship Scale-Short Form (Wei, 2007); Measures two subscales: Anxiety and Avoidance. Attachment style has been shown to be related to measures of wellbeing, we will thus include these subscale scores as predictor variables in our regression analyses as a control variables.

6.	Week of testing: The data for this project have been collected during a period of escalating concern over Covid-19, which may influence responses. We will thus include the week of survey completion as a predictor variable in our regression analyses as a control variable.

hypothesis.value:
We have the following questions (and predictions) that will be addressed:

1.	What is the relationship between interoceptive accuracy and empathy? We predict that there will be a positive relationship between self-report interoceptive accuracy (measured using the Interoceptive Accuracy Scale) and self-report empathy (measured using subscales from a modified/short version of the Empathy Quotient questionnaire).

2.	What is the relationship between interoceptive accuracy, empathy, and wellbeing? We predict that there will be a positive relationship between empathy and both social wellbeing (operationalised as a negative relationship with scores on the UCLA Loneliness Scale), and non-social (mental) wellbeing (operationalised as a positive relationship with scores on the Short Warwick–Edinburgh Mental Wellbeing Scale). Similarly, we predict interoceptive accuracy will be positively linked to both social and mental wellbeing.

3.	Does interoceptive accuracy moderate empathy’s relationship with wellbeing? If interoceptive accuracy and empathy both relate to each other, and to measures of wellbeing independently, we will examine the extent to which empathy-wellbeing relationships are dependant on an interaction with interoceptive accuracy.

Our survey is worldwide, but given the likely main UK base of participants we plan to  restrict our analyses to the UK.

study_type_other.value: Additional Information related to Data Collection Question: Since January 21 2020 we have been conducting a large global survey in collaboration with the BBC and Wellcome Collection. The data will be drawn from a large survey that we are currently conducting collaboration with the BBC and Wellcome Collection (to be completed on 30th March 2020). There are a variety of measures in the survey, but for this project we will extract data specific to empathy, interoceptive accuracy, and wellbeing in order to assess how these factors are related and additional related factors that may contribute to this relationship. As yet we have not accessed the full dataset and will not do so until the survey closes.

attributes.title: ExPra: Team im Leben, Team im Stress

q1.value: Team im Leben, Team im Stress

q2.value: Araniya Girupagaran, Nuria Hilfiker, Michelle Rahm, Benedicta Mohr

q3.value: We will measure jealousy before and after recalling a memory in their current partnership by asking them to write about it in detail. Participants will be divided into four groups and will either write about a situation with jealousy, a situation in which feelings of jealousy were discussed/solved, a situation with envy or their last positive experience in the partnership.

q4.value:
H1: The jealousy score will increase more in the experimental condition "situation with jealousy" than in the condition "situation in which feelings of jealousy were discussed/solved". 
H2: The jealousy score will increase more in the experimental condition "situation with jealousy" than in the condition "situation with envy".
H3: The jealousy score will increase more in the experimental condition "situation with jealousy" than in the control condition "last positive experience in the partnership"

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: It is a mixed (pre-post) design with 4 conditions (situation with jealousy, situation in which feelings of jealousy were discussed/solved, situation with envy and last positive experience in the partnership).

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Participants will be recruited through the psychology mailing list. Participants must be at least 18 years old and at least 6 months in a relationship. Participants will have a chance to win a cinema voucher and psychology students can earn 0.5 "Versuchspersonenstunde".

q13.value: Our taget sample size is 82 participants.

question.value: We manipulated the situation the participants have to recall. It will either be a situation with jealousy, situation in which feelings of jealousy were discussed/solved, situation with envy or last positiv experience in the partnership.

We will measure jealousy by asking them, how jealous they feel, which will be answered on a scale of 1-5, 1 being „not at all“, 5 being „very much“. This item will be integrated in the PANAS. We will also measure socio-demographic information (e.g. age, sex, duration of the relationship), relationship satisfaction with the Relationship Assessment Scale, Jealousy trait with „Vertrauen und Eifersucht bei Paaren“, communication quality with KOMQUAL, affect with PANAS, self-esteem, feeling of control and attachment with relationship questionnaire. We will only analyze the jealousy item.
We will use a Wilcoxon test to to analyze our results.
